part.partText: a long, creeping rhizome anchored in the muddy bottom.
reddish, covered in a gelatinous substance.

alternate, floating, long-stalked (attached to center of leaf), green above, reddish beneath, 4 - 12 cm long, about ½ as wide, oval to elliptic. Leaf stalks and leaf undersides covered in a gelatinous substance.
borne singly on a 5 - 20 cm long stalk, barely emergent, dull reddish purple, to 2.5 cm wide, tepals 6; stamens 12 - 18, erect, anthers deep purple; pistils 4 - 8.
a capsule, 3 - 5 mm long, cylindrical, leathery; seed 2 - 3 mm long, egg-shaped. Capsules ripen underwater and decay to release seeds.

similarSpecies.comments: Brasenia schreberi is the only representative of the family Cabombaceae in the Chicago Region. The gelatinous substance covering its leaf stalks and leaf undersides is unique. It is distinguished from water lilies by not having a slit or notch in its oval leaves.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Found in clear, quiet lakes and ponds. Grows in water 0.5 - 3 m deep. Probably extirpated in some of the Chicago Region counties.

notes.comments: The Japanese use the young leaves and stems in salads. Native Americans once used the rhizomes and leaves for food and medicinal purposes.

etymology.comments: The origin of the word Brasenia is obscure. Schreberi is for Johann Christian Daniel von Schreber, a German botanist and student of Linnaeus in the 18th century.
